message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the Earth's orbit and its relationship to the seasons. The Earth orbits around the sun, which is a plasma star. The tilt of the Earth's axis causes different parts of the Earth to receive different amounts of sunlight at different times of the year, leading to the changes in seasons. Option (A) is incorrect because Mercury is another planet in our solar system and does not cause the seasons. Option (B) is incorrect because Venus is also another planet and does not cause the seasons. Option (C) is incorrect because Pluto, although formerly considered a planet, is now classified as a dwarf planet and does not cause the seasons.

This question requires basic knowledge about the Earth's orbit and its relationship to the seasons. The Earth orbits around the sun, which is a plasma star. As the Earth orbits, its axis is tilted relative to its plane of orbit. This tilt causes different parts of the Earth to receive varying amounts of sunlight throughout the year, leading to the seasons. Option (A) is incorrect because Mercury is also a planet in our solar system, not the object that causes the seasons on Earth. Options (B) and (C) are also incorrect because Venus and Pluto are not the objects that cause the seasons on Earth.

Option (A) is incorrect because Mercury is not responsible for the Earth's seasons. Option (B) is also incorrect because Venus does not affect the Earth's seasons.
